DOC.HEAD: Counterfeiters Beat Soviet Army Watch In Battle for Thai Market
DOC.TEXT: For $110.89, you can watch a Russian revolution once a minute in Bangkok. You can also do pretty much the same for less _ $97.27 less to be precise _ but your version of the Soviet Army Watch will come from Taiwan and not Moscow. Billed by its promoters as the most exciting fashion accessory of 1989, the genuine Soviet Army Watch arrived in Bangkok on Dec. 1, but counterfeit versions have been on open street sale for several months now. Charnchai Kheangprakhong, manager of Zur-Ton International, which markets the real Soviet Army Watch in Thailand, said he is not worried by the flood of cheap imitations. ``It is not a problem _ you can tell which is genuine and which is not _ there is a big difference in quality,'' he said, adding that he expects sales of the real watch to surpass 10,000 in the first year. ``It is a hot fashion item,'' he said. The fake watches came to Thailand partly because of the big demand for them after the Soviet Army Watch was launched in Europe and the United States, he said. ``People couldn't get the real one here so they brought in the fake ones,'' he said. The latest symbol of glasnost is also the latest counterfeit item to be found on the streets of Bangkok. It vies with cheap imitations of Rolex and Cartier watches as well as hundreds of other products including old favorites like Luis Vuitton luggage and Lacoste polo shirts. Most counterfeit products are made domestically, but some imitation watches or watch parts are smuggled in from Taiwan. As one Western businessman living in Thailand remarked: ``Copyright here basically means `the right to copy.'''
